Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Ryan James Oelkers of Texas A&M University to conduct a research project, entitled "Comparing pictures of the night sky to find planets eclipsing stars," during the summer of 2012 at Nanjing University in Nanjing, Jiangsu, China. The host scientist is Ji-Lin Zhou.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is to create and implement a new data reduction technique involving the subtraction of two images. This method can be used to find planets in other solar systems, stars with varying light and supernovae. This research project uses data collected from telescopes in Antarctica.

The Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of this project was to port a difference imaging computer code that would be able to quickly and efficiently move through large data sets. A difference imaging routine involves taking two images of the night sky, taken at differen times and subtracting the two images to look for changes. The computer code effectively matches the two images so they are more or less identical before the subtraction. We can use this routine to find planets around other stars, asteroids, comets, supernovae and variable stars. By the end of the project the difference imaging routine was written in the C computing language and could successfully difference images.

The data reduced in this project came from telescopes positioned on the Antarctic plateau in the south pole. The data from Antarctica is what is a called time-series photometry. This means pictures of the night sky were taken at regular intervals over a long period of time. While this creates a very useful data set, it is large. By putting the computer program in a  computer language such as C, the program can quickly move through the data. It is also possible to adapt it to a large processing super computer. The data from the Antarctic winter season of 2009 has begun to be reduced. Light curves are expected within the coming months. 

The differencing imaging routine can also be used in fields outside of astronomy. Doctors can use the routine to identifty newly formed tumors or cysts. Satellites can use the routine to indentify new structures or changes in landscapes. 

Another key part of the fellowship was its contribution to the 100,000 strong intitiative. It gave me an opportunity to work on my research in China, an opportunity that would have not been available without the NSF. It was important for me to work in China as the telescopes currently installed in Antarctica that are used for this project were created by the Chinese. The project fostered international collaboration and gave me access to data sets not available in the United States.
